locations.name: wat pha luang ta bua tiger temple

text:
twitter TWEET More 
Bangkok: The business people behind Thailand's famous Buddhist Tiger Temple where the bodies of 40 frozen clubs were discovered last year are set to open a new attraction nearby. 
One tour operator is advertising "breakfast with the monks and 150 tigers" at the new centre in Kanchanaburi, a province west of Bangkok, where the Tiger Temple was forced to close last June. SHARE Share on Twitter TWEET Link A tourist poses for a photo with a tiger that is kept in check by a handler's stick, at the Tiger Temple. Photo: World Animal Protection 
As well the tiger cubs found inside a freezer, police discovered the body of a small bear, a set of deer horns and plastic bottles reportedly containing animal parts. 
More than 130 tigers were removed from the temple and taken to breeding stations run by national park authorities. Some were suffering physical deformities allegedly caused by inbreeding. the temple's operators were charged with illegally selling and possessing protected animals. They have denied the allegations. The case has not yet come to court. Related Content Dozens of frozen tiger cubs found in Thai temple amid trafficking fears 
Adisorn Noochamrong, a former official of Thailand's national parks who led the raid on the temple, said the new venture is legal because it has been registered as a zoo. 
"They have the right to do that," he told Thai media, adding the tigers will not be the same ones removed taken from the temple. Advertisement 
They will be animals transferred from a zoo in Nakkon Nayok province. 
The new centre will open under a new company, according to the animal rights organisation World Animal Protection. SHARE Share on Twitter TWEET Link Last year, Thai authorities closed the temple after finding a slaughter house and tiger holding facility they said was used as part of a suspected trafficking network. Photo: AP 
"Given the appalling conditions at the former Tiger Temple, which ultimately led to its closure, we're urging the Thai government not to activate the full zoo licences needed for another tiger entrainment venue to be opened," the organisation saidon its website. 
According to the Tiger Temple website the new centre will require tourists to reserve tickets. Only 30 people will be allowed to visit each day. SHARE Share on Twitter TWEET Link Thai national parks officers carry a sedated tiger at the Wat Pha Luang Ta Bua Tiger Temple on June 1, 2016. Photo: Getty Images 
For years, theTiger Temple was a popular destination for Australian visitors to Thailand. 
Environmentalists estimate there are about 3200 tigers in the country's 17 tiger zoos and farms. SHARE Share on Twitter TWEET Link Remains of tiger cubs and a bear are laid out at the Tiger Temple in Thailand last June. Photo: Supplied 
Environmental groups have called for an end to the use of wild animals for entertainment, including elephant rides, another popular attraction for the millions of tourists who visit Thailand each year. 
Up to 40 people, including six tourists and 30 mahouts (drivers) have been killed by elephants in Thailand in the past 10 years. There also have been attacks by tigers, including on the Tiger Temple abbot, who was mauled in 2015. SHARE Share on Twitter TWEET Link The abbot of the Tiger Temple, Phra Wisutthi Sarathera, is driven past waiting media after authorities found a tiger slaughterhouse. Photo: AP 
Environmentalists point to the use of nails, metal hooks and knives to inflict paid so elephants to perform acts, which is mostly unseen by tourists. 
The Australian tour operator Intrepid Travel was among the first of more than 100 travel companies to stop elephants rides, instead taking tourists to camps where animal welfare is a priority. 
A World Animal Protection survey found 37 per cent of tourists in Thailand said they wanted to ride an elephant and 25 per cent said they would like their photograph taken with a tiger. 
But 85 per cent said they did not want to do anything that would make an animal suffer. Related Content
